thread.title: All Blacks Have the Grit as Well as Swagger
thread.title_full: All Blacks Have the Grit as Well as Swagger

title: All Blacks Have the Grit as Well as Swagger
text:
INDEX All Blacks Have the Grit as Well as Swagger i Ma’a Nonu of New Zealand is tackled during the Rugby World Cup semifinal against South Africa at Twickenham in London on Saturday. The All Blacks ground out a 20-18 win against the Springboks. (Reuters Photo/Stefan Wermuth) By : Justin Palmer | on 8:52 PM October 25, 2015 Category : Sports , Front Page , Rugby 
London. They can win with swagger and a touch of arrogance that defines the All Blacks aura. But New Zealand, as they showed in reaching a second successive World Cup final, can also win ugly through grit, will and self-belief. 
Three defeats in 53 matches since their 2011 World Cup triumph is testament to not only a winning mentality but the strength of character that pervades through Steve Hansen’s side when the going gets tough. 
South Africa made it tough at Twickenham on Saturday and the All Blacks knew they would. They always do. 
All manner of superlatives were heaped on New Zealand, including the label of best team ever by Springboks coach Heyneke Meyer, after their nine-try 62-13 romp against France in the most one-sided quarterfinal of the tournament. 
Hansen branded some of the more outlandish statements as “outrageous” and chose words like composure and leadership to describe a 20-18 victory in the Twickenham drizzle and murk. 
“Great performances don’t always look the same,” Hansen said. 
Just like when they trailed up until the 57th minute in their opening pool match against Argentina – which they could yet meet again in next week’s final – the All Blacks needed to flex their muscles when it mattered. 
Poor discipline had allowed the Springboks to lead 12-7 at the break and flanker Jerome Kaino’s yellow card left New Zealand a man down for the opening minutes of the second half. 
With quarterfinal talisman Julian Savea a peripheral figure with his running lanes shut down, the likes of center Ma’a Nonu and lock Sam Whitelock stepped up. 
Nehe Milner-Skudder made the meters, fullback Ben Smith dealt calmly with the Springbok high bombs, but Nonu shouldered the workload. 
His direct running pushed the Boks back, spinning like a slippery eel out of tackles and providing the run and pass for Neauden Barrett’s 52nd-minute try that turned the game the All Blacks’ way. 
Captain Richie McCaw, who faces an anxious wait to see if he will be cited for a stray elbow on Francois Louw, again took the plaudits for his leadership and work at the breakdown, but the contribution of lock Whitelock in disrupting South Africa’s much-vaunted lineout was just as important. 
And the All Blacks, as McCaw noted, took the few chances that came their way. A killer instinct... 
“We got a couple of opportunities and took them. That’s what you have to do in big games. We took what was on offer,” he said. 
Reuters
